title: Chapter 7. Possible to "Avoid" a lien on a car title loan in a chapter 7?
question: I know there are ways to avoid liens on property. Is it possible to do so on a voluntary lien like this that was taken out against my car?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy documents,Debt,Lien,Debt relief,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,State, local, and municipal law,Vehicle title
answers: No. A lien against the title of a vehicle is not avoidable in Ch 7. I believe redemption of the vehicle would require payment of the full outstanding balance of the loan secured by the lien, as opposed to the value of the vehicle.

Another angle is to make sure the title loan was actually put on title in a timely manner.

We had this happen about a year ago and the lien holder did not put a lien on the vehicle and the lien was fully unsecured.

You never know.

The simple answer is no as explained in the two prior answers. Section 522(f) is used to void judgment liens that infringe on a debtor's exemption in his or her real estate used as a personal resident. However, this cannot be used to void a mortgage which is a voluntary lien.

As my colleague has said, you cannot avoid consensual liens under section 522(f), which is probably what you're thinking of. But car title loans are not legal in all states. Talk to your lawyer, because you may have rights under state law.
No. You can redeem the vehicle by paying what it is worth, but cannot avoid a voluntary lien on your car (see section 522).
